To Present a Proposal for Developing
the Busines Plan for the Ontario
Digital Library
March 21, 203
Ontario’s Digital Library
A Critical Component for Implementing Ontario’s Road Map to
Prosperity Strategy
Sumary
The purpose of this  Request for Proposal  ( RFP ) is to invite firms and/or consultants to
present a proposal for developing the busines plan for the  Ontario Digital Library (ODL).
The ODL wil deliver high-quality library electronic content to al Ontario residents in order to
asist people as they learn, work, and enhance their quality of life. The busines plan to be
developed is to document and clearly comunicate:
how the ODL wil be implemented, including the timeline
the financial plan for the implementation
the financial plan for the first 2 operating years, including capital and operating costs,
revenues, etc.
a financial forecast for the suceding 2 operating years
the services and products to be delivered by the ODL
how the ODL wil operate and be managed folowing the implementation
who wil be involved, and what their role/responsibility wil be, for both the
implementation and operational stages
the marketing and comunications plan for the ODL
This busines plan must be completed and aproved by the ODL Stering Comite no
later than September 30, 203
Timeline:
Those firms/consultants intended to submit a proposal to this RFP must indicate their
intention to do so in an e-mail to Michael Ridley ( mridley@uoguelph.ca ) by  April 1 th .
Proposals may be e-mailed, mailed, couriered or faxed to: Lary More
( lmore@acesola.com ), Executive Director, The Ontario Library Asociation,  10 Lombard
St., Suite 303, Toronto, ON  M5C 1M3.  Proposals must be received by  Non on Monday,
April 21, 203.
Those proposals that are short-listed wil be invited to discus their proposal during the wek
of  April 28, 203 . No presentation wil be expected. Firms or consultants invited to an
interview wil be expected to discus the project and their aproach with the selection
comite .
Contracts with the firm/consultant wil be signed the wek of  May 5, 203  with the work to
comence as son as posible thereafter.
Please note that we reserve the right not to select any of the submited proposals and may
sek further response to these Terms of Reference.
If you require further information or have any questions, please contact Michael Ridley by e-
mail ( mridley@uoguelph.ca )  only  by  3:0 p.m. on Friday April 18th . Al questions and
responses wil be shared with those who have indicated that they wil be submiting a
proposal. Please note, that firms/consultants who have not indicated in an e-mail to Michael
Ridley by April 1 th  that they wil be submiting a proposal wil not receive any further
information or question responses.
Background
First, some background on the ODL. For the last two years the Ontario Library Asociation
has acted as a catalyst, bringing together the stakeholders neded to create the Ontario
Digital Library (ODL). These stakeholders include Ontario’s 50+ public libraries, university,
colege, and schol libraries, as wel as Ontario government ministries.
Libraries that serve very diferent clientele recognize that by working together they can create
seamles aces to quality electronic library services. Through the ODL, students wil be
able to explore a topic at schol, use the same child-safe resources after schol (either at
home or at a public library), enter colege or university with a knowledge of how to use
electronic resources that are stil available and then, after graduation, continue to use these
skils and resources at work or at home.
We are moving into a period of convergence. With convergence we no longer have to license
comercial products as individual libraries or institutions. We can work together to spend our
money wisely. The provincial government has made this posible by working hard to provide
al Ontarians with a stable, high-sped comunications infrastructure. While there is stil a
great deal of work neded to improve this infrastructure, libraries are begining to plan how
best to exploit comunications technology. We can reduce bariers to aces and create the
content infrastructure neded to suport a knowledge society.
The concept of an ODL is a key element in  The Roadmap to Prosperity , a strategic plan to
envision and atain Ontario’s economic goal prepared by the Ontario Jobs and Investment
Board. The OJIB strategic plan recomends an electronic library to “conect students to new
workplaces, new sources of information and aplied learning oportunities”. The ODL wil do
that and much more. The ODL wil conect students to electronic information, and wil also
leverage this investment to help conect al citizens to the electronic information they ned as
they make decisions, solve problems and enhance their quality of life.
Libraries have long ben a key delivery point for public services. The ODL wil alow that
delivery point to move closer to citizens, into the smalest of libraries and even into living
roms.
Libraries have a long tradition of using a practical, consultative aproach to solving problems,
and of learning from others. The ODL is a very practical solution to various problems.
Jurisdiction-wide digital libraries are very practical and very real. The ODL we propose is
leading edge for Ontario but several jurisdictions have forged the path with colaborative
digital libraries. We can learn from their experiences. For example, The Alberta Library (TAL)
was incorporated in 197 as a province-wide library consortium. TAL works colaboratively
with its members to promote universal aces to materials and resources in more than 250
public, post-secondary, special, government and regional libraries. Unlike ODL, TAL does
not include elementary or secondary schols. However, the timeline and funding we are
proposing for ODL is comparable to TAL‘s experience. TAL’s busines planing tok several
years. TAL’s implementation plan was suported by 8 milion dolars in provincialy shared
funding, spread over thre years, later revised to 15 milion dolars over 4 years. Not only is
Alberta’s population 30% of Ontario’s, TAL does not include elementary or secondary
schols as partners; it has 250 member libraries. ODL envisions universal aces for al
10,0,0 Ontarians, with more than 50 Ontario libraries as partners. Although ODL can
learn from TAL’s practices, the scope of planing and implementing ODL is much larger than
TAL.
The ODL wil be a partnership-based organization providing seamles electronic information
services and resources to the citizens of Ontario. It wil use local libraries as the entry point for
comon resources The ODL wil recognize the unique responsibilities and neds of public
libraries, schol libraries, colege and university libraries and special libraries. The ODL
envisions a digital network of information resources, alowing members to colaborate when
there is mutual benefit and to suport the comon mandates of local libraries.
The principles which wil define and guide the ODL are:
Equitable aces for al Ontarians:
We wil bring consistent, high-quality electronic resources and services to 10 milion
Ontario citizens
We wil eliminate bariers to the aces to information and create more consistent
services for library clients.
Shared decision-making and acountability:
We wil facilitate consensus among members regarding ODL’s portfolio of electronic
licenses and services
We wil balance the interests and realities of smal and large as wel as rich and por
comunities and institutions.
Shared governance structure:
We wil share decision-making in order to enable the people we serve.
We wil work based on an underlying asumption of trust and synergy.
Shared funding:
We wil leverage provincial, institutional, and local dolars to realize economies of scale
and put Ontario dolars to work for everyone .
We wil be wiling to pol talents and dolars in order to provide comon services that are
truly greater than those that can be maintained by individual institutions.
Local points of entry:
We wil provide the licenses, infrastructure, services and suport that enable local
libraries to provide exceptional services to their clientele. ODL wil focus on suport,
providing the underpining, not overshadowing.
Services envisioned for the ODL’s include:
Aces:
to the “dep” web (i.e. Comercial, purchased electronic services)
to credible web sites and electronic resources
to digital government information
to local digital colections
Guidance and Advice:
to suport e-learning
to suport citizens, in real-time, as they try to use electronic resources
to asist citizens as they use web-links
Training:
for library workers
for the general public
Provincial Purchasing & Licensing:
of electronic content on a consortia basis for al member libraries
Technological Suport:
of comon standards for the preservation and archiving local digital content
of a comon interface to ODL resources and services that can be imbeded in local
library web sites
What could the ODL realy mean?
For each Ontario citizen it could mean:
One local point of entry to aces seamles electronic library services and
resources for their personal, educational and profesional neds;
Aces to credible, high-quality, user-friendly electronic services through their
comunity, schol, or academic library;
Confidence that the electronic services and sources they – and their children
– are using are safe, valid, and bringing them both global and local
perspectives;
Electronic information and tols that enhance job skils and the learning
experience
For each Ontario student it could mean:
One local point of entry to quality, curiculum- based electronic information
resources and services
Conection to their individual educational environment, whether at the
elementary, secondary or post-secondary levels
Confidence that the services and resources people are using are credible,
available when they ned them and adaptable to diferent learning styles
For each Ontario library it could mean:
One point of entry for themselves and their clientele to quality electronic
resources and services that suport and enhance their colections, programs
and services
The oportunity to show case their local comunity, colections, services, and
expertise
The oportunity to gain from the provincial, colaborative partnership in order
to provide a seamles gateway to digital resources and services
For the Ontario government it could mean:
A  point of entry to information services and resources for al Ontario citizens,
conecting to portal initiatives .
Suport of the Ontario E-Learning strategy through a colaborative digital
library initiative that positions Ontario on the global e-learning scene
Improved aces and flexibility for al students at al ages and stages
(suports Ontario’s lifelong learning strategy)
The oportunity to adres emerging job skils shortages and facilitate schol
to work and job to job transitions with the necesary information and
knowledge suports and tols
ODL wil be an incorporated non-profit organization governed by a Board of Directors elected
by a voting membership. The Board wil include representatives from al stakeholders. We
envision a governance model similar to that prepared for the province’s ORION network.
More information regarding the envisioned phasing, funding and resources required for the
ODL can be found in the apendixes.
The Busines Plan to be Developed
The busines plan which neds to be developed for the ODL must be a formal busines plan
that documents and clearly comunicates the ODL’s services, funding and governance
structures, as wel as implementation plans for 204-205, and operational plans for 205-
The planing proces must also secure the ful comitment of al stakeholders, as
represented on the Stering Comite.
Specificaly, the busines plan must include:
how the ODL wil be implemented, including the timeline
the financial plan for the implementation
the financial plan for the first 2 operating years, including capital and operating costs,
revenues, etc.
a financial forecast for the suceding 2 operating years
the services and products to be delivered by the ODL
how the ODL wil operate and be managed folowing the implementation
who wil be involved, and what their role/responsibility wil be, for both the
implementation and operational stages
the marketing and comunications plan for the ODL
the comitment of al stakeholders to their responsibilities
The proces of developing this busines plan must be extremely consultative to ensure that
al stakeholders are engaged in creating a synergistic ODL organization.  The proposal must
indicate how this consultative proces wil be aproached.
The busines plan for the ODL must adres significant isues. There are, for example,
enormous diferences in the financial resources available to libraries mandated to provide
similar services. Some post-secondary and public libraries, particularly those in large urban
areas, have the facilities, funding and technological infrastructure necesary to service their
patrons with electronic services and resources.  Many others, particularly in rural regions, do
not.  The proposal must indicate how these isues wil be aproached.
Milestones
1) A preliminary report wil be isued during June 203.
2) It is expected that an Interim Report, suitable for distribution to the broader library
comunity wil be available by August 1, 203 and that there wil be an oportunity
for responses to be evaluated.
3) The busines plan must be completed and aproved by the ODL Stering Comite
no later than September 30, 203.
Aproach and Specific Proposal Requirements
The firm/consultant  (or proposed team of consultants)  wil be expected to work closely with
the ODL Stering Comite. Terms of reference for the Comite are in the apendix.
Given the consultative nature of this busines planing proces, the firm/consultant wil also
be expected to travel and comunicate regularly with various stakeholders as wel as with
electronic resource publishers/vendors.
The proposal should include the folowing information:
a) name of the firm/consultant
b) names of those individuals who wil be engaged in this project, their specific
responsibilities on this project and relevant experience/qualifications
c) description of similar engagements that highlight the firm’s experience in busines
planing and building stakeholder comitment
d) references with details of work completed for these references
e) description of the aproach that wil be used for completing the busines plan,
including a timeline
f) cost to complete the study including estimated expenses (i.e.: travel, etc.) and payment
structure
Evaluation and Awarding of Contract
The contract wil be awarded to the bider whose submision ofers the best value; the contract wil
not necesarily be awarded to the lowest bider. We reserve the right not to award the contract to
any of the biders responding to this RFP and we may sek further response.
Specificaly, proposals wil be evaluated proposals acording to the folowing criteria:
Quality of the proposal /aproach outlined for undertaking the busines planing proces
Demonstrated experience
Cost, including expenses
Timeline and projected completion date
Other relevant factors as determined by the ODL Stering Comite
Questions regarding this RFP should be directed by e-mail only to Michael Ridley
(mridley@uoguelph.ca).
Biders are asked not to contact any other member of the ODL Catalyst Team or the ODL Stering
Comite.
